It's a champagne moment in the fight against Ebola, according to Doctors without Borders.
In a small trial, an experimental vaccine protected 100 percent of the people at high risk for the virus.
The results are preliminary, but the study offers new hope of wiping out Ebola in West Africa.
NPR's Michaeleen Doucleff has this report.
When Ebola exploded last summer, scientists around the world all agreed on one thing.
To stop this epidemic quickly, we need a vaccine.
Dr. Marie-Paule Kieny, an assistant director general at the World Health Organization, says they may have just reached that goal.
It is a game changer because there was nothing -nothing - against Ebola that could protect the people.
This is the very first intervention against Ebola.
The vaccine was developed by the Canadian Public Health Agency, and Kieny has been leading a clinical trial in Guinea since last April.
She and her team published the results of that trial this week in The Lancet.
She says the vaccine is safe and stops the virus in its tracks.
When we discussed with our colleagues who are doing the response to Ebola, they told us it's strange.
There are cases, cases, cases in this community, then we vaccinate, and the cases seem to disappear.
In fact, there are so few cases in Guinea that Kieny and her team couldn't use the standard method for testing a vaccine.
The team had to come up with a whole new design for the trial.
The strategy uses what's called ring vaccination.
When a case crops up, the team rushes to the sick person, then they give the vaccine to the people who are high risk of getting Ebola - those who are close to the sick person.
So this can be the neighbors, the family, the co-workers.
So this forms what is called a ring.
These are the people who are from the community around the case.
Over the past few months, the team identified about 4,000 people in these so-called rings.
They divided them up into two groups.
Half got vaccinated immediately, and the others had to wait three weeks to get the shot.
The results were striking.
In the group that got vaccinated immediately, no one got Ebola.
No cases anymore - finished, zero.
So this provides an estimate of efficacy, of course, of a hundred percent.
Which sounds amazing, even unbelievable, and Kieny says it actually is.
The problem is there were only 16 cases of Ebola in the group that didn't get the vaccine right away.
That's way too small of a number to say for sure how well the vaccine works, but Kieny thinks its efficacy is probably closer 70 percent.
